conclusion: Analyze the p-V diagram and use thermodynamics principles to compare internal energy at states a and c.
The cycle consists of four processes: c to b (isochoric), b to d (adiabatic), d to a (isochoric), and a to c (adiabatic).
For an adiabatic process in an ideal gas, PV^γ = constant, and no heat is exchanged (Q = 0), so change in internal energy is due to work.
In an isochoric process, volume remains constant, work done is zero (W = 0), so change in internal energy equals heat added or removed (ΔU = Q).
Internal energy of an ideal gas depends only on temperature. For a monoatomic ideal gas, U = (3/2) nRT.
Comparing internal energies at states a and c requires comparing their temperatures.
From the p-V diagram, adiabatic curves show higher pressure at the same volume corresponds to higher temperature.
State c has higher pressure than state a at the same volume, so temperature at state c is greater than at state a.
Since temperature at state c is higher than at state a, internal energy at state c is greater than at state a.
